questions.text: A 33-year-old male with schizophrenia is being evaluated in an inpatient ward. He is asked what he would do if he smelled smoke and saw flames coming from his neighbor’s home. The commonly asked question is what would the patient do if he sees a "house on fire" and the response is evaluated. Personal judgment: Here, the patient is asked about the plans for his future life, and the response is evaluated. Social judgment: Here, the patient's ability to interact appropriately in social situations is evaluated

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the epidemiology of schizophrenia?

options.label: D
options.text: More common in lower socioeconomic status due to downward drift

questions.correct_answer: D. More common in lower socioeconomic status due to downward drift
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) More common in lower socioeconomic status due to downward drift

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Worldwide lifetime prevalence of Schizophrenia is approximately 0.7 per cent. Both men and women are equally affected, but the onset of the illness tends to be earlier in males and later in females. The peak age of onset for schizophrenia is in adolescence and young adulthood, typically between 15 and 24 years. However, there is also a second peak in middle age for females. If the onset occurs after the age of 45, it is referred to as "late-onset schizophrenia." It is more common in lower socioeconomic classes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with schizophrenia has poor eye contact, monotone speech, diminished interest in social interaction, and no facial expressions. These are most likely due to:

options.label: B

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negative symptoms of schizophrenia—such as blunted affect, social withdrawal, and reduced motivation—are linked to dopamine hypofunction in the mesocortical pathway. This contrasts with positive symptoms, which are due to dopaminergic hyperactivity in the mesolimbic pathway.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 361.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with schizophrenia developed torticollis and oculogyric crisis 3 hours after haloperidol administration. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer intramuscular promethazine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotics can be seen within minutes of receiving an injectable antipsychotic (also with oral antipsychotic). It is characterized by sudden contraction of a muscle group and can lead to symptoms like torticollis (twisting of the neck), oculogyric crisis (deviation of eyeballs), opisthotonos (extreme arching of the back), trismus (contraction of jaw muscles) or other dystonic reactions. Treatment of acute dystonia involves immediate administration of parental anticholinergics such as benztropine, promethazine, or diphenhydramine. To prevent acute dystonia, prophylactic use of oral anticholinergics is suggested while prescribing typical antipsychotics.
  • ➤ earliest side effect
  • ➤ sudden contraction
  • ➤ torticollis
  • ➤ oculogyric crisis
  • ➤ opisthotonos
  • ➤ anticholinergics

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is found sitting motionless in the same posture for hours. On passive movement of her arm, it remains fixed in place. She is mute and resists movement slightly. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Catatonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The term catatonia was given by Karl Kahlbaum . Catatonia is a psychiatric emergency that is characterized by severe motor abnormalities such as akinetic mutism (stupor), excitement, waxy flexibility, posturing, catalepsy, automatic obedience, negativism, Gegenhalten, psychological pillow etc. The lorazepam challenge test aids in prompt diagnosis. Lorazepam is first line treatment for catatonia.
  • ➤ catatonia
  • ➤ Karl Kahlbaum
  • ➤ Lorazepam
  • ➤ first line treatment

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 345-346.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with major depressive disorder complains of sexual side effects after starting antidepressant therapy. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause sexual dysfunction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bupropion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido and difficulty maintaining an erection, is a common side effect of SSRIs like fluoxetine. These medications increase serotonin levels, which can adversely affect sexual desire and performance. In contrast, antidepressants like mirtazapine and bupropion are less likely to cause sexual dysfunction and may even be used to mitigate these side effects when they occur with other antidepressants.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 628-630.

  • ➤ For patients with major depressive disorder and active suicide risk , ECT is the most effective and fastest-acting treatment , often life-saving. It is preferred over psychotherapy or antidepressants when immediate improvement is needed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with acute-onset chest pain, palpitations, dizziness, and a choking sensation. She reports a “feeling of impending doom” and insists she is having a heart attack. ECG and cardiac enzymes are normal. These episodes have occurred multiple times in the past month, lasting 15–30 minutes each. She now avoids going outside for fear of an attack. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Panic disorder with agoraphobia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Panic disorder with agoraphobia is diagnosed when a patient experiences recurrent, spontaneous panic attacks along with persistent concern about having more attacks and avoidance of situations where escape might be difficult. Recognition is key to preventing worsening avoidance and functional impairment.
  • ➤ Panic disorder with agoraphobia
  • ➤ recurrent, spontaneous panic attacks
  • ➤ persistent concern about having more attacks
  • ➤ avoidance of situations

questions.text: A 32-year-old office worker reports persistent tension, restlessness, and fatigue for over 8 months. He constantly worries about minor issues such as meeting deadlines, managing household chores, and his family’s health. He also complains of muscle tension, insomnia, and poor concentration. There are no panic attacks or mood disturbances. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate prescription of benzodiazepines for long-term control

options.label: C
options.text: Initiation of SSRI and cognitive behavioral therapy

Ans. C) Initiation of SSRI and cognitive behavioral therapy

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) is best managed with a combination of SSRIs and cognitive behavioral therapy , which address both the neurochemical and cognitive-behavioral factors underlying the condition. Benzodiazepines are not suitable for long-term management , and treatment should focus on functional recovery, not avoidance behaviors like bed rest.
  • ➤ Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
  • ➤ SSRIs and cognitive behavioral therapy
  • ➤ Benzodiazepines are not suitable for long-term management

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student avoids giving presentations or answering questions in class due to fear of being humiliated.   • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Social Anxiety Disorder is best managed initially with CBT and SSRIs , which together target the core cognitive, emotional, and behavioral features of the disorder. Benzodiazepines or beta-blockers may have limited, adjunctive roles , but they are not appropriate for first-line or long-term treatment .

questions.text: A 29-year-old software engineer presents with complaints of persistent intrusive thoughts about germs and contamination. He spends over 3 hours daily washing his hands and cleaning his surroundings, despite realizing the thoughts are irrational. He reports distress and occupational dysfunction due to his symptoms. He tries to resist these thoughts but fails. Which of the following features best supports the diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)?

options.text: Insight into the irrationality of thoughts

questions.correct_answer: C. Insight into the irrationality of thoughts
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Insight into the irrationality of thoughts

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A defining feature of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder is that the person often has insight into the irrationality of their intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors, yet feels driven to perform them to reduce distress. This ego-dystonic quality helps distinguish OCD from other psychiatric conditions like delusional disorder or personality disorders.
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
  • ➤ insight into the irrationality
  • ➤ driven to perform them
  • ➤ ego-dystonic quality

questions.text: Match the following OCD symptom clusters with their common features:

  • ➤ CBT-based exposure and response prevention

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought by his parents due to sudden onset of repetitive hand washing, throat clearing, and blinking tics. These symptoms developed acutely after he recovered from a sore throat. There is no previous psychiatric history. Labs confirm a recent streptococcal infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans. B) PANDAS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PANDAS is characterized by the sudden onset of OCD symptoms and/or tics in children , typically following a group A streptococcal infection . Recognizing this autoimmune neuropsychiatric syndrome is critical, as treatment may include antibiotics, immunomodulation , and psychiatric interventions to manage symptoms effectively.
  • ➤ PANDAS
  • ➤ sudden onset of OCD symptoms and/or tics in children
  • ➤ group A streptococcal infection
  • ➤ antibiotics, immunomodulation
  • ➤ psychiatric interventions

  • ➤ Obsessions are intrusive, ego-dystonic thoughts that are recognized by the individual as irrational , and they often attempt to resist them. This distinguishes them from delusions (fixed, false beliefs held with conviction) and thought insertion (psychotic belief that thoughts are imposed by an external source).

  • ➤ delusions
  • ➤ thought insertion

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the psychiatry outpatient clinic by her sister for repeated episodes of stealing. The patient admits to experiencing a growing tension before each act and describes a sense of relief immediately after stealing. She reports no monetary or material need for the stolen items, which she often discards later. She denies hallucinations, delusions, or mood symptoms. There is no substance use or conduct disorder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kleptomania

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kleptomania is an impulse control disorder marked by repetitive stealing of items not needed , preceded by tension and followed by relief , and is not motivated by material gain . It is distinct from antisocial behavior and other psychiatric conditions that may involve stealing.
  • ➤ Kleptomania
  • ➤ impulse control disorder
  • ➤ repetitive stealing of items not needed
  • ➤ tension and followed by relief
  • ➤ not motivated by material gain

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who survived a bomb blast 2 months ago reports vivid nightmares, flashbacks, and avoids public transport. He is easily startled and feels emotionally numb. He reports these symptoms began 3 weeks after the event and are ongoing. Which of the following criteria must be met to diagnose PTSD?

options.label: A

options.label: D
options.text: Symptoms persisting for more than one month

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PTSD is diagnosed when symptoms such as intrusions, avoidance, negative mood/cognition changes, and hyperarousal persist for more than one month after a traumatic event and lead to significant functional impairment . Early recognition and treatment are crucial to reduce long-term psychological consequences.
  • ➤ PTSD
  • ➤ intrusions, avoidance, negative mood/cognition changes, and hyperarousal
  • ➤ more than one month

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice for PTSD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for PTSD is trauma-focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) , which addresses the core cognitive, emotional, and behavioral aspects of the disorder. While EMDR is also effective, benzodiazepines should be avoided , and supportive psychotherapy alone is insufficient for sustained recovery.
  • ➤ treatment of choice for PTSD
  • ➤ trauma-focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
  • ➤ EMDR
  • ➤ benzodiazepines should be avoided

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with insomnia, flashbacks, and heightened anxiety following a road traffic accident 10 days ago. She avoids the accident site and is hypervigilant. Symptoms started 5 days after the trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute stress disorder

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are features of complex PTSD except:

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with sadness, insomnia, and poor appetite for the past 2 weeks after losing his job. He reports mild functional impairment but no suicidal ideation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of diffuse abdominal pain, headaches, and fatigue for the past 6 months. questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Somatic symptom disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Somatic Symptom Disorder is diagnosed when one or more physical symptoms cause disproportionate distress and functional impairment , with excessive health-related thoughts or behaviors . Unlike malingering or factitious disorder, the symptoms are not intentionally produced , and the distress is authentic and clinically significant .

  • ➤ disproportionate distress and functional impairment
  • ➤ excessive health-related thoughts or behaviors

  • ➤ authentic and clinically significant

questions.text: La belle indifférence is most characteristically associated with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conversion disorder

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

This helps distinguish it from conditions involving intentional symptom production .
  • ➤ La belle indifférence
  • ➤ classic but not pathognomonic feature

  • ➤ unexpected lack of concern
  • ➤ intentional symptom production

questions.text: A 29-year-old hospital technician presents with abdominal pain and requests morphine for relief. He has numerous surgical scars on his abdomen. options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. Obvious external incentives such as avoiding jail
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Obvious external incentives such as avoiding jail

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malingering is characterized by the intentional feigning of illness for external gain , unlike factitious disorder , where the motive is to assume the sick role without external incentives . Identifying clear external motives (e.g., obtaining drugs or avoiding jail) is the strongest clue to malingering.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, which she claims started suddenly after eating at a restaurant. Her medical records show multiple previous visits to different hospitals for a variety of unexplained symptoms, including headaches, chest pain, and nausea. Physical examination and laboratory investigations are repeatedly normal. She frequently uses medical jargon and becomes irritated when told no cause is found. She appears calm when being informed about plans for endoscopy. Which of the following statements regarding her likely condition is incorrect?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) External rewards such as financial benefit are the primary motivation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factitious disorder involves intentional symptom production without external incentives , motivated by a psychological need to assume the sick role . In contrast, malingering is driven by clear external rewards . Understanding this distinction is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Factitious disorder
  • ➤ intentional symptom production without external incentives
  • ➤ psychological need to assume the sick role
  • ➤ malingering
  • ➤ clear external rewards

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. Although he sustained no major injuries and has a clear sensorium, he insists that nothing happened and that his parents, who died in the accident, are waiting at home. CT brain is normal. questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dissociative amnesia often presents after severe psychological trauma , with inability to recall important autobiographical information , typically regarding the traumatic event. It is not due to a neurological condition and often involves psychological defense mechanisms like denial and detachment.
  • ➤ Dissociative amnesia
  • ➤ severe psychological trauma
  • ➤ inability to recall important autobiographical information
  • ➤ not due to a neurological condition
  • ➤ psychological defense mechanisms

questions.text: Match the Type with Dissociative Subtype:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D

  • ➤ distinctive clinical features

  • ➤ not under voluntary control

questions.text: A 40-year-old prison inmate is admitted for psychiatric evaluation after providing approximate answers to simple questions. questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ganser syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganser syndrome is a dissociative disorder marked by approximate answers , commonly seen in forensic or high-stress settings . It is distinct from malingering due to the presence of bizarre but patterned behavior and possible altered mental status , with unconscious psychological motives rather than deliberate deception.
  • ➤ Ganser syndrome
  • ➤ dissociative disorder
  • ➤ approximate answers
  • ➤ forensic or high-stress settings
  • ➤ bizarre but patterned behavior

questions.text: Match the Following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic is admitted for confusion, unsteady gait, and involuntary eye movements. Neurologic exam reveals horizontal nystagmus and ataxia. MRI shows mammillary body atrophy. What is the next best step in management?

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer IV thiamine before glucose

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young man is found unconscious with pinpoint pupils, shallow breathing, and bluish lips. EMS suspects opioid overdose. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IV naloxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected opioid overdose , IV naloxone is the first-line emergency treatment . It rapidly reverses respiratory depression and sedation , potentially saving the patient’s life. Always assess airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) while administering naloxone.
  • ➤ opioid overdose
  • ➤ IV naloxone
  • ➤ first-line emergency treatment
  • ➤ respiratory depression and sedation
  • ➤ airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the most effective pharmacologic treatment for tobacco cessation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Varenicline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varenicline is currently the most effective pharmacologic agent for tobacco cessation due to its dual action in reducing cravings and blocking nicotine reward. It should be considered first-line therapy , particularly in motivated smokers without contraindications.
  • ➤ Varenicline
  • ➤ most effective pharmacologic agent
  • ➤ dual action
  • ➤ first-line therapy

questions.text: A college student reports having intense visual hallucinations similar to a past "trip" after using LSD 3 months ago. He has not used any substances recently. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flashback

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flashbacks or Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder (HPPD) involve recurrent perceptual symptoms after past hallucinogen use, especially LSD , and can occur without recent drug intake . Recognition of this condition is important to differentiate it from primary psychotic disorders.
  • ➤ Flashbacks

  • ➤ LSD
  • ➤ without recent drug intake

questions.text: Which substance is most strongly associated with the development of amotivational syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic cannabis use is most strongly associated with amotivational syndrome , particularly in young individuals , leading to reduced interest in goal-directed activities, academic performance, and social engagement . Early identification and intervention are key to preventing long-term functional impairment.
  • ➤ Chronic cannabis use
  • ➤ amotivational syndrome
  • ➤ young individuals
  • ➤ reduced interest in goal-directed activities, academic performance, and social engagement

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with paranoia, tactile hallucinations ("bugs crawling"), mydriasis, and severe agitation. He has been using an unknown substance over the weekend. Which substance is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication can lead to severe agitation, paranoia, mydriasis, and tactile hallucinations (formication) . These features help differentiate it from other substances and indicate the need for prompt supportive care and possible sedation .
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication
  • ➤ severe agitation, paranoia, mydriasis, and tactile hallucinations (formication)
  • ➤ prompt supportive care and possible sedation

questions.text: A college student is brought in after a party. He has red conjunctiva, dry mouth, increased appetite, and reports euphoria. No psychosis or seizures are noted. What is the most likely substance involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cannabis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cannabis intoxication is commonly associated with conjunctival injection, dry mouth, increased appetite, and euphoria . These features are distinctive and help differentiate it from other substances used recreationally.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the ED after a wrist-cutting episode. She has a long history of unstable interpersonal relationships, impulsive behavior, and frequent mood swings. She says she often feels empty and fears abandonment. Her relationships fluctuate between idealization and devaluation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dialectical behavior therapy

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) is the most effective and evidence-based treatment for Borderline Personality Disorder , especially for managing impulsivity, self-harm, and emotional dysregulation . Early intervention with DBT can significantly improve outcomes and reduce the risk of recurrent crises.
  • ➤ Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)
  • ➤ most effective and evidence-based treatment
  • ➤ Borderline Personality Disorder
  • ➤ impulsivity, self-harm, and emotional dysregulation

questions.text: A 28-year-old man prefers solitary activities, shows little emotion, and has no interest in sexual relationships or forming close friendships. He denies delusions or hallucinations and does not report magical thinking. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schizoid personality disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schizoid personality disorder is defined by emotional detachment , social withdrawal , and indifference to relationships , without the eccentric thoughts of schizotypal or the fear-driven avoidance seen in avoidant personality disorder.
  • ➤ Schizoid personality disorder
  • ➤ emotional detachment
  • ➤ social withdrawal
  • ➤ indifference to relationships

questions.text: A 40-year-old bank manager is described by his coworkers as a perfectionist who insists everything must be done his way. He is extremely preoccupied with rules, reluctant to delegate tasks, and has no time for leisure or relationships. He has no history of compulsions or obsessions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD) involves a rigid preoccupation with orderliness, control, and perfectionism at the expense of flexibility and relationships. Unlike OCD, OCPD does not involve true obsessions or compulsions , and the behaviors are typically ego-syntonic .
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD)

  • ➤ not involve true obsessions or compulsions
  • ➤ ego-syntonic

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is referred by her primary care doctor due to repeated ER visits for self-inflicted cuts. She describes intense relationships that often shift quickly from admiration to hatred. She reports chronic feelings of emptiness, anger outbursts, and impulsive spending. She says, “I just want to feel something real.” There are no hallucinations or delusions. Which of the following features is most characteristic of her condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Identity disturbance and emotional dysregulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Identity disturbance and emotional dysregulation

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Borderline Personality Disorder is marked by emotional instability, impulsivity, identity disturbance , and intense fear of abandonment . Self-harming behaviors and unstable interpersonal dynamics are common. Treatment often includes Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) , which targets emotion regulation and interpersonal effectiveness .

  • ➤ emotional instability, impulsivity, identity disturbance
  • ➤ intense fear of abandonment
  • ➤ Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)
  • ➤ emotion regulation and interpersonal effectiveness

questions.text: A 19-year-old female restricts food intake to very low levels but reports no episodes of binging or purging. She has a BMI of 15.8, irregular periods, and constantly rearranges food on her plate during meals. Which subtype of anorexia nervosa is most consistent with this presentation?

Ans. B) Restricting type

  • ➤ restricting type
  • ➤ severe caloric restriction

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student reports excessive daytime sleepiness, despite getting adequate sleep at night. He describes episodes of sudden muscle weakness triggered by laughter and brief visual hallucinations before falling asleep. His sleep study shows decreased REM latency.   • ➤ Narcolepsy type 1 is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness , cataplexy , sleep paralysis , and REM-related hallucinations . Polysomnography shows decreased REM latency , and CSF analysis often reveals low hypocretin levels . Recognizing these REM intrusion phenomena is essential for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic after he was found sleepwalking and mumbling at night. He had no memory of the episode. These events usually occur within 2 hours of sleep onset. Which of the following sleep stages is most likely involved?

  • ➤ Sleepwalking and related parasomnias (e.g., night terrors) arise from deep NREM sleep (stages 3 and 4) , usually within the first third of the night . These events are non-REM arousal disorders , common in children, and are characterized by amnesia for the event and lack of dream recall .

questions.text: Which of the following best distinguishes nightmare disorder from sleep terror disorder?

  • ➤ confusional arousals

questions.text: Which of the following features is most specific for Rett syndrome?

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with repeated eye blinking and facial twitching. He also makes grunting noises involuntarily. These symptoms began at age 9 and have waxed and waned. He has also been diagnosed with ADHD. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy struggles with reading and frequently reverses letters. He makes spelling mistakes despite normal IQ and does well in other subjects. His math skills are appropriate for age. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ aggression, theft, and cruelty

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoing psychodynamic psychotherapy begins to express intense feelings of love and admiration toward her male therapist, describing him as “just like her father who always protected her.” The therapist recognizes these feelings as reflective of past emotional relationships.   • ➤ Transference involves the redirection of emotions from past relationships onto the therapist , often revealing unresolved conflicts or emotional patterns. Recognizing and working through transference is a key mechanism of change in psychodynamic psychotherapy .

  • ➤ key mechanism of change
